awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  RUI: Diversity of modulation and functional flexibility in small neuronal networks: An evolutionary and mechanistic approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Rhythmic movements, such as heartbeat and locomotion, must be flexible to allow animals to alter their behavior in response to changing conditions. Rhythmic movements are controlled by networks of nerve cells that interact with one another to produce patterns of nerve impulses that drive appropriate muscle movements. To alter movement patterns, these neural networks rely on the actions of chemical compounds called neuromodulators; these compounds alter (modulate) the properties and interactions of the cells in the network, thereby enabling them to alter the pattern of movements that are generated by the network. Such alterations include, for example, changes in the speed of the resulting behavior or the coordination of muscles that control different portions of the movement pattern. There is evidence, however, that the extent to which similar networks can be altered ("modulatory capacity") varies among species. This project addresses two fundamental questions related to this variability in modulatory capacity: first, on an evolutionary timescale, what variables determine the extent to which networks can be modulated, and second, what factors/mechanisms underlie differences in modulatory capacity. In addition to addressing these questions using as exemplars the stomatogastric network and the cardiac network in a crab that eats only kelp versus a crab that eats many different kinds of food, the current project also prepares the next generation of scientists by (1) training high school students and undergraduates in a variety of research techniques, as well as in designing experiments and in analyzing and presenting data, and (2) providing continuity and potential expansion of the neuroscience component of a program that engages 7th grade Native Americans in Maine in science to enhance their educational aspirations and success in high school and beyond.

This project uses the stomatogastric and cardiac networks of closely related majoid crab species with vastly different dietary diversity to test the hypothesis that modulatory capacity is an important evolutionary substrate for diversity within any given behavior, and to ask what mechanisms underlie differences in modulatory capacity. Current data suggest that the stomatogastric network in Pugettia producta, a species that eats only kelp, is not responsive to many modulators that alter the network in another majoid, Libinia emarginata, which has a highly diverse diet. This project expands the number of neuromodulators tested, as well as examines and compares modulation of the cardiac network in the same species. The investigators use transcriptomics and mass spectrometry to identify native isoforms of peptide modulators in these majoids, then use physiological recordings to compare the modulatory capacities of the Pugettia and Libinia stomatogastric and cardiac neuromuscular systems. The prediction is that modulatory capacity in the Pugettia stomatogastric system is less than that of the opportunistic feeder, but that modulation in systems that are presumably subject to similar demands for flexibility, e.g., the cardiac neuromuscular system, is not markedly different. To examine the mechanisms that underlie changes in modulatory capacity, the investigators use transcriptomics, testing the hypothesis that the mechanism underlying decreased modulatory capacity of the Pugettia stomatogastric system is an absence or decreased abundance of receptors to those modulators. Transcriptomics results are confirmed using qRT-PCR and through expression of the receptors of the two species to compare relative binding affinities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rhythmic movements, like walking or breathing, are controlled by networks of nerve cells (neurons) whose patterned outputs generate those movements. Although these networks are considered to be 'hard-wired', they can be modulated by chemicals (neurotransmitters and neuropeptides) to enable a single network to produce an array of variants of the behavior. Crustaceans are employed as model organisms to study rhythmic patterns; the relatively simple networks controlling the heart and stomach provide valuable information that informs our understanding of more complex nervous systems. In particular, the stomatogastric nervous system, which controls the rhythmic contractions of the muscles responsible for processing food in the stomachs of crabs and lobsters, has been extensively studied; the network is well-understood, and a large number of molecules that modulate its outputs have been identified. Although modulators likely serve multiple functions, one hypothesis is that they enable the behavioral flexibility needed to allow the animal to function optimally as conditions, such as food being processed, change. Thus, modulation could serve as an evolutionary mechanism to allow appropriate levels of behavioral flexibility. Species with more modulation could eat diverse foods, while species with restricted diets might decrease the extent to which these networks are modulated, i.e., their modulatory capacity.

This study addressed two fundamental questions related to modulatory capacity: first, on an evolutionary timescale, what variables determine the extent to which networks can be modulated, and second, what factors/mechanisms underlie differences in modulatory capacity. We specifically studied modulation of the nervous systems of three closely related crabs: Pugettia producta (kelp crab), Libinia emarginata (spider crab), and Chionoecetes opilio (snow crab). Our previous study found that the stomatogastric system of the kelp crab was not modulated by several neuromodulators that activate the stomatogastric networks of previously studied crab species (e.g. the relatively distantly related Jonah crab). Moreover, the kelp crab, as suggested by its name, has a very restricted diet: it eats almost exclusively one item, kelp, while the other species have highly variable diets. This unique behavior enabled us to ask whether the reduced modulatory capacity of the kelp crab is related to dietary variability by comparing the modulatory capacities of the stomatogastric system in the kelp crab to that of the two omnivorous species. To determine whether reduced modulatory capacity is limited to the stomatogastric system, we examined modulation of the crustacean heart as a control.

Differences in modulatory capacity, putatively related to diet, are hypothesized to result from an absence or reduced concentration of the modulatory neuropeptides or from a reduction of receptor expression. To determine if modulatory neuropeptides were present in the three species, we generated and mined transcriptomes (containing the genetic information needed by the organism to generate neuropeptides) and then analyzed tissue samples using mass spectrometry to verify that the modulatory neuropeptides were present.

To determine whether modulatory capacities of the stomatogastric system or the heart differed across species, we applied 12 potential modulators to the stomatogastric system and the heart in each species. Our data are consistent with our hypothesis: the stomatogastric system of the kelp crab responded to fewer modulators than those of either the spider crab or the snow crab, whereas the modulatory capacities of the cardiac system were not correlated with diet, suggesting that one role of modulators is indeed to serve as a mechanism enabling needed behavioral flexibility. Surprisingly, the hearts were not all modulated equally. Instead, the snow crab heart responded more extensively than did the hearts of the other two species, suggesting that there are additional factors involved in determining modulatory capacity and additional roles played by modulators.

This project also contributed to preparing the next generation of scientists through training biology/neuroscience and chemistry undergraduates in a variety of research techniques, as well as in designing experiments, in analyzing and presenting data, and in promoting interdisciplinary connections that span the use of genetic/transcriptomic data, mass spectrometry, and electrophysiology. Over the course of the grant, over 50 undergraduates participated in research in the PI and co-PI's labs. Additionally, the grant contributed to the training of six high school students, who conducted mentored summer research projects. The grant also helped to engage 7th grade Native Americans in Maine in science, with a goal of enhancing their educational aspirations and success in high school and beyond. The PI, postdoc, and students working in the PI's lab helped run a weeklong program designed to inspire these students to consider continuing in science.  Finally, the grant was key in training a postdoctoral fellow, who was mentored in research, in working with undergraduate and high school students, and in teaching at the undergraduate level. As the grant is ending, he is starting a position as an Assistant Professor in a liberal arts college, where he will continue this line of research and continue mentoring undergraduate and high school students.
